responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Insecure Storage of Password in Redis
    analysis: |
      The `RedisDao` class stores the password for the Redis server in plaintext within the `password` field. This field is not protected in any way, meaning that if an attacker gains access to the Jenkins server, they will be able to read the Redis password.
    cwe: CWE-922
    function_names:
      - RedisDao
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/jenkins/plugins/logstash/persistence/RedisDao.java
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: Missing Authentication for Critical Function in SyslogDao
    analysis: |
      The `SyslogDao` class does not implement any authentication mechanisms when sending syslog messages. This means that an attacker on the network could potentially send arbitrary syslog messages to the configured syslog server, potentially leading to log injection or denial-of-service attacks.
    cwe: CWE-306
    function_names:
      - push
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/jenkins/plugins/logstash/persistence/SyslogDao.java
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Insecure Storage of Password in Redis
leads.analysis: The RedisDao class stores the password for the Redis server in plaintext within the password field. This field is not protected in any way, meaning that if an attacker gains access to the Jenkins server, they will be able to read the Redis password.

leads.headline: Missing Authentication for Critical Function in SyslogDao
leads.analysis: The SyslogDao class does not implement any authentication mechanisms when sending syslog messages. This means that an attacker on the network could potentially send arbitrary syslog messages to the configured syslog server, potentially leading to log injection or denial-of-service attacks.
